data.title: Test stable Windows 64 bit ad
data.body:
@egamma Remember that we moved the windows 64 bit ad to the top of the release notes: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/commit/7f7d770e921f91250ec94cd897ec832832cb06a8

Once the docs are published, and ideally before they actually are, we should test that the following URL puts users in the right place:

`https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_15#_windows-64-bit`

cc @gregvanl

data.title: onDidChangeWorkspaceRoots comes too early
data.body:
`onDidChangeWorkspaceRoots` event comes too early. If i try to get the configuration of one of the roots I get undefined results.

I believe the onDidChangeWorkspaceRoots events should come only after I am able to read settings from all the roots

data.title: Select next and previous problem
data.body:
I've found a bug in VSCode. In first, I'm using MacOSX.  
  
When I press **Command+U** to go back to the previous selection (or point of a snippet) and I press **Command+D** again to select the next match (or point of a snippet), the VSCode takes me to the point **AFTER of what I expect**.  
  
**IN EXAMPLE:** we have the points **1**, **2**, **3**, **4**, **5** of a snippet. I'm currently in the 2. I press **Command+U** to back to the **1**, so I press **Command+D** to match the next (and **I expect to go to 2** again) and it takes me to the 3 (it continues increasing erroneous).  
  
What we could do to solve that?

data.title: Add markdown links
data.body:
testing #31475

I'd suggest to add some links when writing jsdoc, like `passing a DebugConfiguration` should become `passing a [DebugConfiguration](#DebugConfiguration)`. Such links will work in the generated version (https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api) and there is also a special link provider that should make them work within vscode.d.ts

data.title: Is `workbench` a good name?
data.body:
testing #31448

When defining a config setting from an extension I can define its scope. One value is `workbench` which looks like an internal name. How about `editor`?

data.title: Consider to move optional argument to the end
data.body:
testing #31475

The signature of `startDebugging` marks the first parameter as optional'ish which looks a little weird to me. I would have written it the other way around. Unsure why it done this way?

```ts
export function startDebugging(nameOrConfiguration: string | DebugConfiguration, folder?: WorkspaceFolder): Thenable<boolean>;

```

data.title: Recently opened files is just a bucket and not sorted by recency
data.body: I have a multi-root workspace with the vscode-sources and an extension (called 'virtual'). Both folders have `vscode.d.ts` and while I surely have opened both files at least once, I have opened `vscode.d.ts` from the vscode-sources at least 1000-times more often (and more recent). Still, the file picker presents the `vscode.d.ts` from the extension on top, always. It seems like I once made a mistake to open the wrong vscode.d.ts-file and I am still being punished for that.

data.title: How do I handle type assertion in vanilla Javascript when using checkJs?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-27-generic

---

I've [asked the same question on StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45353770/how-do-i-convince-the-typescript-checker-that-a-value-is-a-specific-subclass-in) but I'm rephrasing it here.  I'm worried that the answer to "how do I do this?" will wind up being "oh crap, you can't, we didn't think of that."

1. Enable type checking on Javascript files (`compilerOptions.checkJs=true` in `jsconfig.json`)
2. Write the following code in a `.js` file:
        let el = document.querySelector("#definitelyAnImage");
        el.src = "image.png";
3. Notice that `.src` gets marked as an error -- this is because `querySelector` returns an `Element` but the `.src` property is defined on the subclass HTMLImageElement.

In Typescript, I gather the solution would be to use a type-assertion before accessing the subclass property, or use `as HTMLImageElement` in the initial assignment.  What can I do to get rid of this error in vanilla JS?

data.title: Configuration.update does not seem to have effect
Improve API configuration `update()` error message
data.body:
Testing #31448 

I attempted to write to a non-resource setting from an extension, under the folder scope. I got this error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22350/28674991-cb081b24-72e6-11e7-849b-99309e2db133.png)

Shouldn't the error be more specific? Something in the lines of:

> The `xxx` setting can't be set under the `yyy` configuration target because zzz.

Something like that?

---

Related to #31541 due to wording

data.title: Settings API: How to write to folder settings?
data.body:
Testing #31448

I can't figure out how I can write to the folder settings from the API.

I'm in a workspace with two folders open. I have the same settings configuration as in #31576. In the API I attempt to write them both to the folder scope:

```ts
config.update('resourceBrand', value, vscode.ConfigurationTarget.WorkspaceFolder);
config.update('brand', value, vscode.ConfigurationTarget.WorkspaceFolder);
```

Both calls fail with:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22350/28674357-769439e8-72e5-11e7-9f0b-40f3984e7bf7.png)

Nothing ever gets written to the folder settings.

How do I even specify **which** folder the setting should go to?

data.title: Add option to open recent workspace in new window
data.body: It should be possible to open a recently closed workspace in a new window by clicking on "Open Recent" -> "NAME (workspace)". Currently, it seems to replace the workspace in the current window.

data.title: onDidTerminateDebugSession asymmetry
data.body:
testing #31475

We have `onDidStartDebugSession` and `onDidTerminateDebugSession` and I feel that `start` and `terminate` isn't a good couple. Maybe `start` and `stop` or `launch` and `terminate`?

data.title: Not able to run debug configurations named the same
data.body:
Testing #31396

1. Have a workspace with `css` and `html` extensions.
2. Run `Launch Extension (css)` configuration -> Debug starts
3. Run `Launch Extension (html)` configuration

Observe that no new debug session is started.

data.title: Add editor action for closing all diff editors at once

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a new editor action that greatly improves one of my most common workflows, and that I think may be encountered by other people using VS Code with settings similar to my own.

**Scenario:**

I always have VS Code configured with `"workbench.editor.enablePreview": false`, because I find that I generally want files to be kept open after navigating to them and there is less friction when I don't have to remember to double-click. The tradeoff is that when prepping my changes for commit, all of the diff viewers will remain open as well.

**Proposal:**

Add a "Close All Diff Editors" command to the relevant context menus, so that the user can get rid of all the diff views in one shot once they've finished using them, but still leave all their code editors open to continue working. This is especially useful for anyone that likes to make lots of bite-sized local commits.

This is implemented in the service-layer as a more generic "close everything of a specified type", but the only action wired up to it currently is for diff views.

**Demo:**

![close-diff-editors](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1147216/28673626-047b8516-72b1-11e7-8ed1-4d8b676cd957.gif)

data.title: Extension development shouldn't check for engines.vscode being *
data.body:
Testing #31448

We often have to change `engines.vscode` to `*` in order to get the latest `vscode.d.ts` while developing an extension. If you F5 that extension you'll get an error that the vscode version isn't valid. This is always such a pain to go through every time one needs to test an extension using a new API.

IMO in extension development mode, the extension should still be loaded. This error shouldn't be there.

data.title: can read/write folder settings in single folder setup
Settings: gray out decoration comes too late
data.body:
Refs: #31448

1. Multi root workspace, open folder settings
2. Add some forbiden setting like workbench.colorTheme, notice that it does not get greyed out. So now me as a user am puzzled why it is not being applied
3. If i press enter it gets greyed out or if I open the file again

I think you should update all decorations on every save event in the settings file

data.title: Weird selection color of setting on margin hover
data.body:
Refs: #31448

Hover over the margin in the settings, notice we use a weird color to decorate the settings line.
In light theme it is banana yellow and in dark it is gray.
I do not think we use these colors in other places. Could we instead use a well known color?

Maybe the debug top stack frame decoration color?

![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 15 10 49](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28671749-0ec70ffe-72de-11e7-9e48-6440b9566439.png)

data.title: "Compare with Saved" editor shows stale data after file has been saved
data.body:
Testing #30721:

- turn off auto save
- make sure to show the "Open Editors" section in the explorer
- edit a file "xyz.txt" (or whatever)
- execute "Compare with Saved" action on the dirty editor in the "Open Editors" section
- save the dirty editor for "xyz.txt" in the "Open Editors" section

Observe: the "Compare with Saved" editor still shows the differences and even labels the right side "xyz.txt (on disk)". 

After the save of the changes the Compare editor should not show any differences (or should at least use a correct label).
